title: Duranta erecta
text:
Duranta erecta is a species of <a href="Flowering%20plant">flowering</a> <a href="shrub">shrub</a> in the <a href="verbena">verbena</a> family <a href="Verbenaceae">Verbenaceae</a>, native from Mexico to South America and the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>. It is widely cultivated as an <a href="ornamental%20plant">ornamental plant</a> in <a href="Tropics">tropical</a> and <a href="Subtropics">subtropical</a> gardens throughout the world, and has become <a href="Naturalisation%20%28biology%29">naturalized</a> in many places. Common names include golden dewdrop, pigeon berry, and skyflower.
Description.
"Duranta erecta" is a sprawling <a href="shrub">shrub</a> or (infrequently) a small <a href="tree">tree</a>. It can grow to tall and can spread to an equal width. Mature specimens possess axillary <a href="Thorns%2C%20spines%2C%20and%20prickles">thorns</a>, which are often absent on younger specimens. The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> are light green, elliptic to ovate, opposite, and grow up to long and broad, with a 1.5 cm petiole.
The <a href="flower">flower</a>s are light-blue or lavender, produced in tight <a href="Inflorescence">clusters</a> located on terminal and axillary stems, sometimes appearing as <a href="panicles">panicles</a>, frequently recurved or pendulous, blooming in summer. The <a href="fruit">fruit</a> is a small globose yellow or orange <a href="Berry%20%28botany%29">berry</a>, up to diameter and containing several <a href="seed">seed</a>s.
Taxonomy.
The genus name is in honor of <a href="Castore%20Durante">Castore Durante</a>, a fifteenth-century Italian botanist. The <a href="specific%20name%20%28botany%29">specific epithet</a> "erecta" means "upright" in <a href="Latin">Latin</a>. The plant is also known as "D. repens", from the Latin for "creeping". The latter name was originally used to identify smaller-leaved <a href="Variety%20%28botany%29">varieties</a> of the species.
Ecology.
"Duranta erecta" is native to the Americas, from Mexico and the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> south to Brazil and Argentina. There is some debate about whether the plant is also native to the southern United States, in <a href="Florida">Florida</a>, <a href="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>, <a href="Texas">Texas</a>, <a href="Arizona">Arizona</a> and <a href="California">California</a>, or is an <a href="introduced%20species">introduced species</a> there, at an altitude of 40–1100 meters above sea level.
In its natural state, it commonly grows in rocky or <a href="sand">sand</a>y <a href="coast">coast</a>al areas with full sun, or moister, <a href="Ruderal%20species">disturbed sites</a> inland. Prior to maturity, the plant will grow at a rate of up to half a meter per year.
Cultivation.
Golden dewdrop is widely grown as an <a href="ornamental%20plant">ornamental plant</a> throughout <a href="Tropics">tropical</a> and warm <a href="Subtropics">subtropical</a> regions. Its showy <a href="flower">flower</a>s and <a href="fruit">fruit</a> make it a desirable addition to gardens, and the blossoms attract <a href="Butterfly">butterflies</a> and <a href="hummingbird">hummingbird</a>s. There are a wide variety of <a href="cultivar">cultivar</a>s available, including 'Alba', 'Aurea', 'Aussie Gold', 'Gold Mound', 'Geisha Girl', 'Sapphire Showers', and 'Variegata'.
Invasive potential.
The plant has been identified as an <a href="invasive%20species">invasive species</a> in Australia, South Asia, China, South Africa, <a href="Hawaii">Hawaii</a>, <a href="Fiji">Fiji</a> and <a href="French%20Polynesia">French Polynesia</a>. It has been introduced to other habitats but has not become invasive.
Properties.
The leaves and unripened berries of the plant are <a href="Toxin">toxic</a>, and are confirmed to have killed children, dogs and cats. However, <a href="songbird">songbird</a>s eat the fruit without ill effects.
<a href="Antioxidative">Antioxidative</a> <a href="coumarinolignoid">coumarinolignoid</a>s called repenins have been isolated from "Duranta erecta".
In the fruit, the <a href="alkaloids">alkaloids</a>, <a href="isoquinoline">isoquinoline</a>, and a derivative of 5,6-dihydro-7H-2-<a href="pyridine">pyridine</a> in addition to the <a href="monoterpenes">monoterpenes</a> durantoside I, durantoside and repenoside have been identified .
The leaves and fruits of D. repens contain a saponin glycoside and the presence of hydrocyanic acid . The durantoside has been detected in leaves and stems with leaves, in addition to the amide in the last sample. The isoquinoline is lethal to insects.
